content.body: Is it specced that adding a fetch event listener in the service worker after first run will do something weird? https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#add-an-event-listener just says "might not have expected results" but I can't find any spec mechanism that could generate those wrong results.
Ah I think I found it: https://w3c.github.io/ServiceWorker/#run-service-worker-algorithm step 17.1
Domenic: yeah, service workers violates the don't look at events thingie :-/
content.formatted_body: Domenic: yeah, service workers violates the don't look at events thingie :-/

content.body: I've come to peace with it, service workers are weird.
Domenic: did you have a chance to look at https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/pull/38150 again?
content.formatted_body: Domenic: did you have a chance to look at https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/pull/38150 again?

content.body: Domenic: I also found that we have `url-setters-stripping.any.js` which might make some of these a bit redundant
content.formatted_body: Domenic: I also found that we have url-setters-stripping.any.js which might make some of these a bit redundant

content.body: Hey all. I built a toy a while ago: https://foolip.github.io/spec-reactions/
Sorting by recent reactions and filtering to WHATWG gives this:

> <@annevk:matrix.org> Domenic: did you have a chance to look at https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/pull/38150 again?

I did not sadly; I am content with the new tests but I do wish I had time to investigate why we were passing before.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:matrix.org
Domenic: did you have a chance to look at https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/pull/38150 again?
I did not sadly; I am content with the new tests but I do wish I had time to investigate why we were passing before.

content.body: Does that seem like it could correspond with things that are worth extra attention?
I like it, foolip! I've been rooting for observables in particular for some time :)
Ah yes, https://github.com/whatwg/dom/issues/544 wins the total reactions battle, but seems to have fallen quite lately.
Domenic: I'm going to merge to not block other implementers (and given the other existing tests); I can file an issue on jsdom if you want?
content.formatted_body: Domenic: I'm going to merge to not block other implementers (and given the other existing tests); I can file an issue on jsdom if you want?

content.body: Sounds good, and yeah a tracking issue would be quite lovely.

annevk: What is supposed to make the iframes not inherit UTF-8 from the same-origin parent harness in WebKit and Blink in https://wpt.fyi/results/encoding/unsupported-labels.window.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned&view=subtest ?
content.formatted_body: annevk: What is supposed to make the iframes not inherit UTF-8 from the same-origin parent harness in WebKit and Blink in https://wpt.fyi/results/encoding/unsupported-labels.window.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned&view=subtest ?

content.body: hsivonen: I think Firefox might have a different default encoding maybe due to your work?
content.formatted_body: hsivonen: I think Firefox might have a different default encoding maybe due to your work?

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: hsivonen: I think Firefox might have a different default encoding maybe due to your work?
hsivonen: I think Firefox might have a different default encoding maybe due to your work?

content.body: hsivonen: if that's not it I guess I need to take a longer look
content.formatted_body: hsivonen: if that's not it I guess I need to take a longer look

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: hsivonen: if that's not it I guess I need to take a longer look
hsivonen: if that's not it I guess I need to take a longer look

content.body: annevk: but Chrome uses utf-8 in the parent document too, and I assume so does Safari
content.formatted_body: annevk: but Chrome uses utf-8 in the parent document too, and I assume so does Safari

content.body: annevk: Without inheritance, if the content is ASCII, Firefox defaults to windows-1252. However, in the test case, the parent declares UTF-8, so that's inheritable within the same origin.
content.formatted_body: annevk: Without inheritance, if the content is ASCII, Firefox defaults to windows-1252. However, in the test case, the parent declares UTF-8, so that's inheritable within the same origin.

content.body: Interesting, so these always failed in Gecko?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Interesting, so these always failed in Gecko?

content.body: annevk: Yes, it looks like this test has failed since it synced to m-c in October. It's unfortunate that we don't have automated notifications for new tests that fail.
content.formatted_body: annevk: Yes, it looks like this test has failed since it synced to m-c in October. It's unfortunate that we don't have automated notifications for new tests that fail.

content.body: hsivonen: you were the reviewer! 😀
content.formatted_body: hsivonen: you were the reviewer! 😀

content.body: I can take a look later today most likely
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I can take a look later today most likely

content.body: smaug: hsivonen: it seems that once Content-Type charset is involved there's no more cross-document inheritance, regardless of whether that charset value is correct, in Chromium and WebKit
content.formatted_body: smaug: hsivonen: it seems that once Content-Type charset is involved there's no more cross-document inheritance, regardless of whether that charset value is correct, in Chromium and WebKit

content.body: https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/pull/38199 demonstrates this, though it could test more

smaug: hsivonen: I guess I clean those tests up, and also make the `encoding/` tests use `<meta>` instead for now so we don't run into this particular issue. And then file bugs against Chromium/WebKit or open a spec issue to see if we want to collectively reconsider given that more sites might rely on Chromium/WebKit behavior at this point...
content.formatted_body: smaug: hsivonen: I guess I clean those tests up, and also make the encoding/ tests use <meta> instead for now so we don't run into this particular issue. And then file bugs against Chromium/WebKit or open a spec issue to see if we want to collectively reconsider given that more sites might rely on Chromium/WebKit behavior at this point...

content.body: annevk: ok, thanks!
content.formatted_body: annevk: ok, thanks!

content.body: Anybody here know much about Chrome's use-counter data? I'm looking for numbers on the CSS `:has` pseudoselector, but I can't find a use counter. That seems surprising for such a popular and difficult-to-implement feature, so I'm wondering if I'm looking in the wrong place. https://chromestatus.com/metrics/css/popularity
content.formatted_body: Anybody here know much about Chrome's use-counter data? I'm looking for numbers on the CSS :has pseudoselector, but I can't find a use counter. That seems surprising for such a popular and difficult-to-implement feature, so I'm wondering if I'm looking in the wrong place. https://chromestatus.com/metrics/css/popularity

content.body: jugglinmike: search for "cssselectorpseudohas" in https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/popularity (not so appropriately named "JS/HTML" in the menu)
content.formatted_body: jugglinmike: search for "cssselectorpseudohas" in https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/popularity (not so appropriately named "JS/HTML" in the menu)

content.body: There are several and I don't know the difference between them
But you can look up how they're implemented in https://source.chromium.org/chromium
Excellent; thanks, zcorpan !
content.formatted_body: Excellent; thanks, zcorpan !

content.body: Maybe snapshot profile means querySelector{,All}() and live profile means CSS
Filed https://github.com/GoogleChrome/chromium-dashboard/issues/2694

> <@zcorpan:mozilla.org> Maybe snapshot profile means querySelector{,All}() and live profile means CSS

yes, that's roughly correct (also Element.matches and Element.closest); these used to be distinguished in the CSS Selectors spec but no longer are
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @zcorpan:mozilla.org
Maybe snapshot profile means querySelector{,All}() and live profile means CSS
yes, that's roughly correct (also Element.matches and Element.closest); these used to be distinguished in the CSS Selectors spec but no longer are

content.body: Jeremy Roman: Thanks for clarifying. It seems like binning the data like that makes it difficult to answer the question, "how often is :has used?" since there's no telling how many pages use it in both contexts. Is that right?
content.formatted_body: Jeremy Roman: Thanks for clarifying. It seems like binning the data like that makes it difficult to answer the question, "how often is :has used?" since there's no telling how many pages use it in both contexts. Is that right?

content.body: Ah, scratch that--"CSSSelectorPseudoHas" is a dedicated flag!
Except, it looks like it has never been used. Hinky
